Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Piety[ENDCOLOR] is the measurement of your adherence to your religion. Piety is needed to ensure a healthy religion; that your people continue to follow it and well. As time and the number of adherents of your State Religion go on, your Piety will fall. It is your duty to maintain it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Piety is accumulated through a number of sources, such as through Wonders or Policies, but mainly it is generated from your Follower Belief. The specific means of accumulating Piety depends upon the specific Follower Belief that your religion follows.

Your [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Piety Level[ENDCOLOR] is the state of your Piety, and describes one of five states: Devout, Virtuous, Neutral, Poor, and Heretical. At higher levels of Piety, you will receive religious bonuses. Conversely, at lower levels, you will receive religious penalties.

Your [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]State Religion[ENDCOLOR] is the prerequisite to having Piety. It is the religion that you designate as the religion of your people. You may choose any religion to become your State Religion, so long as you have met the founder and have researched Priesthood. If you have founded a religion, this will automatically become your State Religion once you research Priesthood. You may change your State Religion at any time, but this will usually cost Faith or incur Resistance in cities following your current one.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Other Civilizations or City-States may adopt your religion as their State Religion. They are more likely to do this when that religion is in the majority of their cities and if they like you. This will influence your Piety Per Turn when you are above or below its resting rate.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Secularization[ENDCOLOR] is the process whereby you dismantle your State Religion and separate it from government. Secularizing your State Religion may be done once you have researched Scientific Theory, and will disable your Piety and associated bonuses and penalties.
Body of Mary of the Divine Heart
Armor Piece of Guru Gobhind Singh

Use [ICON_PEACE] Faith to purchase Renaissance Era (and later) land units.
Missionaries heal adjacent Units by 5 HP per turn and Inquisitors reduce adjacent enemy [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength by 5%

+25% [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety from all sources and 2 free Inquisitors appear near the city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Must be built in a Holy City. Must have built a Monastery in all Cities. The cost goes up the more cities there are in the empire.

An important building for a civilization trying to defend against heresy, the Grand Inquisition increases the amount of [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety you earn from all sources by +25%. A civilization must have a Monastery in all cities before it can construct the Grand Inquisition.

Grand Inquisitor was the lead official of the Inquisition. The title usually refers to the chief inquisitor of the Spanish Inquisition, even after the reunification of the inquisitions. Secretaries-general of the Roman Inquisition were often styled as Grand Inquisitor but the role and functions were different. The most famous Inquisitor General was the Spanish Dominican Tomás de Torquemada, who spearheaded the Spanish Inquisition.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health, and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.
Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense, [ICON_JFD_RES_SAFFRON] Saffron, and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

Each source of [ICON_RES_INCENSE] Incense, [ICON_JFD_RES_SAFFRON] Saffron, and [ICON_RES_WINE] Wine worked by this City produce +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +1 [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health, and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense and/or Wine resources.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense and/or Wine resources.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith, [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health, and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense and/or Wine resources.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense, Saffron, and/or Wine resources.
Monasteries increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith, [ICON_JFD_HEALTH] Health, and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output, especially if the city is near to improved Incense, Saffron, and/or Wine resources.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Altars belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Melee and Gun Units may earn [ICON_PEACE] Faith from kills.

Ritual sacrifice is a custom much interwoven in many traditional religions. It is the offering of food, objects, or the lives of animals or humans to a higher purpose; in particular to divine beings. Human sacrifice, the kind implied here, was widespread throughout the ancient world - particularly in Pre-Columbian America. The Aztec Empire is notorious for its human sacrifices, held on an unusually large scale in offering to the sun.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Basilicas belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A basilica is a type of building, usually a Christian church, that is typically rectangular with a central nave and aisles, usually with a slightly raised platform and an apse at one or both ends. In Europe and the Americas it is the most common architectural style for churches though this building plan has become less dominant in new buildings since the later 20th century. Today the term basilica is often used to refer to any large, ornate church building, especially Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox, even if it does not strictly follow this style.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Cathedrals belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Churches belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
+33% religious pressure emanating from this City.

A church building, often simply called a church, is a building used for religious activities, particularly worship services. The term in its architectural sense is most often used by Christians to refer to their religious buildings but can be used by other religions. In traditional Christian architecture, the church is often arranged in the shape of a Christian cross. When viewed from plan view the longest part of a cross is represented by the aisle and the junction of the cross is located at the altar area.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Daoguans belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A Daoguan is a place of worship in Taoism. The structure and function of a Daoguan can vary according to the Taoist school the temple belongs to. For example, guān of the Quanzhen School are monasteries where celibate daoshi live.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Fire Temples belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A fire temple in Zoroastrianism is the place of worship for Zoroastrians, often called dar-e mehr (Persian) or agiyari (Gujarati). In the Zoroastrian religion, fire (see Atar), together with clean water (see Aban), are agents of ritual purity. Clean, white "ash for the purification ceremonies [is] regarded as the basis of ritual life", which "are essentially the rites proper to the tending of a domestic fire, for the temple [fire] is that of the hearth fire raised to a new solemnity". As of 2017, there were 50 fire temples in Mumbai, 100 in the rest of India, and 27 in the rest of the world.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Gurdwaras belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A Gurdwara is the place of worship for Sikhs; however, people of all faiths are welcomed in the Sikh Gurdwara. The gurdwara has a Darbar Sahib where the Guru Granth Sahib is seen and a Langar where people can eat free food served by the Sikh community. A gurdwara may also have a library, nursery, and classroom. A gurdwara can be identified from a distance by tall flagpoles bearing the Nishan Sahib, the Sikh flag.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Hermetic Orders belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

The Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn was an organization devoted to the study and practice of the occult, metaphysics, and paranormal activities during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Known as a magical order, the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn was active in Great Britain and focused its practices on theurgy and spiritual development. Many present-day concepts of ritual and magic that are at the centre of contemporary traditions, such as Wicca and Thelema, were inspired by the Golden Dawn, which became one of the largest single influences on 20th-century Western occultism.

In addition to the +2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith provided by the Temple which it replaces, the Koil also provides +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every 2 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in the city. This building will be extremely useful in accumulating [ICON_PEACE] Faith through the ages, especially in tall empires. Only India may build it

A Koil, literally "King's House," is a term for a distinct type of Hindu Temple with Dravidian architecture. It consists of temples with pyramid shaped towers, constructed of sandstone, soapstone, or granite. It is one of three styles of temple mentioned in the ancient book Vastu shastra. Empires such as the Row, the Chera, and the Vijayanagara constructed many of these temples.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Mandirs belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A Mandir is a Hinduist or Jainist temple. The word comes from the Sanskrit ‘mandira', which means ‘house', ‘palace' or ‘temple'. Hundreds of mandirs are spread throughout India and Southeast Asia, where they are called Candi or Wat, amongst other names. A single mandir is often dedicated to a single deity. A brightly decorated altar of the god or goddess is the centre of the temple, where people come to worship and meditate. In some religious complexes there are many individual shrines placed over a larger area, forming one mandir; in others multiple shrines are part of one building. Such temples would often be accompanied by a well or pool of water, where ritual bathing takes place, required before any prayer. One of the most famous and largest mandirs is the Prambanan temple in Indonesia, made of stone in 9th century AD.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Mosques belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Ovoos belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

Ovoo or obo are sacred stone heaps used as altars or shrines in Mongolian folk religious practice and in the religion of other Mongolic peoples. They are usually made from rocks with wood. Ovoos are often found at the top of mountains and in high places, like mountain passes. In modern times, especially in China, some of them have developed into large and elaborate structures becoming more like temples than simple altars. In many of these aobaoes of China, a trident symbol is put on top of the structure.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Pagodas belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Synagogues belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A synagogue, also spelled synagog, is a Jewish house of prayer. Synagogues have a large hall for prayer (the main sanctuary), and may also have smaller rooms for study and sometimes a social hall and offices. Some have a separate room for Torah study, called the beth midrash.
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Temples of Literature belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.

A temple of Confucius or Confucian temple is a temple for the veneration of Confucius and the sages and philosophers of Confucianism in Chinese folk religion and other East Asian religions. They were formerly the site of the administration of the imperial examination in China and Vietnam and often housed schools and other studying facilities. The temples are known by a variety of names throughout East Asia. The two greatest temples in Qufu and Beijing are now known in Chinese as "Temples of Confucius" =. In Shanghai, Vietnam, Korea, and Indonesia, they are known as "Temples of Literature" or "Temples of the Sage of Literature" (Vietnamese: văn thánh miếu).
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Torii Gates belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
Infantry Units purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith spawn Great Generals 33% faster.

A torii is a traditional gateway found at the entrance to Shinto Shrines. They mark the transition from the profane to the sacred, and are commonly found throughout Japan. Torii were traditionally made from wood or stone, but today are also made of concrete, copper, or steel. They are typically left unpainted or are painted vermilion.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Islamic faith.
Receives the Great General Combat Bonus.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the East Orthodox faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Shinto faith.
Heals 15 Hit Points when defeating an enemy unit.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Tlateomatiliztli faith.
Generates [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great General Points from kills.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Hindi faith.
Ranged attacks may be performed over obstacles (as long as other friendly units can see the target).
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Sikh faith.
Adjacent Units heal 5 Hit Points per turn.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Zoroastrian faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Tengrii faith.
May pillage tile improvements without expending Movement.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Roman Catholic faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Protestant faith.
Forces defender to retreat if it inflicts more damage than it receives. A defender who cannot retreat takes extra damage.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Jewish faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Confucian faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Hermetic faith.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Buddhist faith.
Earns [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points from kills.
A military order dedicated to the protection of the Taoist faith.
They believe you are a heathen.
They believe you are a heathen (but they tolerate heathens).
They appreciate our devotion to their State Religion.
You are the Defender of the Faith for their State Religion.
Your claim to the Mandate of Heaven is fallacious.

Replace.Text: Books are expensive; a finely illustrated book is even more so. Regardless, as a faithful follower of {1_Religion}, we should obtain a copy.[NEWLINE]

------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Requirements:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must not have researched Printing Press. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Costs:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{2_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

[NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rewards:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{1_Num} [ICON_PEACE] Faith. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Note: The [ICON_PEACE] Faith reward increases with your [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety Level.
The Church lacks men to lead it. We are in a position to correct this. Let us aid the Church in seeking out wise and godly men to appoint as the leaders of Christianity![NEWLINE]
Let us commemorate in a humble feast the blessed saints who, unknown or known, have served to guide the word of God into our hearts and spirits.[NEWLINE]
Let us commemorate in a humble feast the blessed saints who, unknown or known, have served to guide the word of God into our hearts and spirits.[NEWLINE]

Row.Text: This order will consume the unit and restore your [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety to full.
Unit must be stationed in a Holy City and at full Health, and you must have a State Religion.
This order will consume the unit and create a Great General.
Unit must be stationed in a City and at full Health.
This order will consume the unit and grant an additional Belief for your Religion.
Unit must be stationed in a Holy City and at full Health.
This order will consume the unit and grant 2 [ICON_JFD_CLERIC] Clerics.
+25% conversion of cities to this religion. Bonus relations with civilizations following this State Religion.

[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It will cost you [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{2_Num}[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_PEACE] Faith to change your State Religion or to Secularize. This cost will increase at higher Piety Levels and with the number of cities following your State Religion.

[ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}% conversion of [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens to this religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries have +50% [ICON_MISSIONARY] Conversion Strength.

[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It will cost you [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{2_Num}[ENDCOLOR] [ICON_PEACE] Faith to change your State Religion or to Secularize. This cost will increase at higher Piety Levels and with the number of cities following your State Religion.
[ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}% conversion of [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens away from this religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries have -50% [ICON_MISSIONARY] Conversion Strength.

[ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}% conversion of [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens away from this religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries have -50% [ICON_MISSIONARY] Conversion Strength.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Increases [ICON_JFD_CRIME_BLACK] Crime from [ICON_JFD_CRIME_FAITH] Heresy by +50%.

[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It will incur [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]{1_Num}[ENDCOLOR] Turn(s) of [ICON_RESISTANCE] Resistance in all cities following your State Religion if you change your State Religion or Secularize. This number will increase at lower Piety Levels.

[ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}% conversion of [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens away from this religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Penalty to relations with civilizations following this State Religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries have -75% [ICON_MISSIONARY] Conversion Strength[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries may spread their religion one less time.

[ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}% conversion of [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens away from this religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Penalty to relations with civilizations following this State Religion.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionaries have -75% [ICON_MISSIONARY] Conversion Strength.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Missionares may spread their religion one less time.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Increases [ICON_JFD_CRIME_BLACK] Crime from [ICON_JFD_CRIME_FAITH] Heresy by +100%.

Forces all Civilizations to secularize. Increases generation of Great Scientists, Engineers, and Merchants by 15%.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Piety[ENDCOLOR] increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith of empires and the [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety of State Religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Piety allows you to [ICON_PRODUCTION] build Shrines, Temples, and Monasteries in half the usual time. Unlocks building the Mosque of Djenne.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all Policies in the Piety tree causes a Great Prophet to appear and Holy Sites provide +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Piety[ENDCOLOR] increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith of empires and the [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety of State Religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Piety allows you to [ICON_PRODUCTION] build Shrines, Temples, and Monasteries in half the usual time. Unlocks building the Mosque of Djenne.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all Policies in the Piety tree causes a Great Prophet to appear and Holy Sites provide +3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture. It also allows the purchase of Great Doctors with [ICON_PEACE] Faith starting in the Industrial Era.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Infallibility[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]20% discount on all [ICON_PEACE] Faith purchases. Gain [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety when purchasing Great Prophets, Missionaries, and Inquisitors.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Infallibility[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Gain [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety when purchasing a Great Prophet, Missionary, or Inquisitor. When [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety is Devout or Virtuous, converts followers of foreign religions as well.

Infallbility is the philosophical doctrine concerned with reality and truth. In Christian theology, it is the inability to err when speaking on revelation. In the Catholic Church, the doctrine of Papal Infallability asserts that, when exercising the office of St. Peter, as by the promise of St. Peter, the Pope cannot speak in error.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]+{1_Num}[ENDCOLOR] when purchasing Great Prophets, Missionaries, and Inquisitors.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Organized Religion[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from Shrines and Temples.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Syncretism[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]When [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety is above Neutral, converts followers of foreign religions as well. Increases [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety resting rate by +15.

Syncretism is the combining of different, often contradictory beliefs, while melding practices of various schools of thought. Syncretism involves the merger and analogizing of several originally discrete traditions, especially in the theology and mythology of religion, thus asserting an underlying unity and allowing for an inclusive approach to other faiths. Syncretism also occurs commonly in expressions of arts and culture (known as eclecticism) as well as politics (syncretic politics).
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT][ICON_BULLET]+{1_Num}[ENDCOLOR] to your resting rate from Syncretism.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Monastic Education[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Free Monastery in first four cities and Monk specialists yield +1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science.

A monastery is a building or complex of buildings housing monks or nuns - people who have renounced worldly things (wealth, possessions, sex) - and dedicated their lives to prayer and meditation. Generally monasteries are single-sex organizations, or if men and women are present, they're separated by imposing walls. Historically monasteries have been places of higher learning, especially during the Middle Ages where members of religious orders were often the only people outside of the ruling elite who knew how to read and write.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Inquisition[ENDCOLOR] grants +1 [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety per turn, but may only be built in cities not following your State Religion.
Enables conversion of Production into Piety.
When next to an enemy city, other units within 2 tiles get a 50% Bonus when attacking the city.
+2/+5% city [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points when garrisoned.
+10% [ICON_STENGTH] Combat Strength when adjacent to a Missionary.
All units in adjacent tiles [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Heal 10 Additional HP[ENDCOLOR] per turn.
A unit born to serve their faith.
Earns [ICON_PEACE] Faith from kills equal to 100% of the enemy's [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength.
Earn points toward a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age for each enemy killed.
Increases Great General spawn rate by 33%.
Enemy units receive -10% [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength when adjacent to any unit with this promotion.

"That which is below is like that which is above, and that which is above is like that which is below, to do the miracles of one only thing."[NEWLINE]- Emerald Tablet[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hermeticism is a philosophical-religious movement contemporaneous with and arising from the same influences as Gnosticism and Neoplatonism. The tradition is based primarily on pseudepigraphical writings attributed to Hermes Trismegistus; a syncretic combination of the Greek Hermes and the Egyptian Thoth that arose in the oriental Alexandrine atmosphere of late antiquity.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The importance of Hermeticism comes from its rediscovery during the Renaissance where, largely mixed with Neoplatonic philosophy, it served as the backdrop for the development of modern magical traditions as well as contributing to the development of modern science. The prominence that it gave to the idea of influencing or controlling nature led many scientists to look to the Occult Sciences (e.g., magic, alchemy, astrology) which, it was thought, could put Nature to the test by means of experiments.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Hermeticism was understood as part of prisca theologia; a doctrine which affirms that a single, true theology exists which is present in all religions and was given by God to man in antiquity. Many scientists placed great faith in the concept of an unadulterated, pure, ancient doctrine, which could be studied to aid in understanding the physical world.

The Mesoamerican religions of Central America represent a closely related but distinct group of faiths, many of which had elements of human sacrifice in connection with a large number of religious festivals which were held according to astrological calendars.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Aztec world consisted of three main parts: the earth world on which humans lived, an underworld which belonged to the dead, and the upper plane in the sky. The earth and the underworld were both open for humans to enter, whereas the upper plane in the sky was impenetrable to humans. Existence was envisioned as straddling the two worlds in a cycle of birth, life, death, and rebirth. Thus as the sun was believed to dwell in the underworld at night in order to be reborn in the morning and maize kernels were interred to later sprout anew, so the human and divine existence was also envisioned as being cyclical.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sacrificial rituals among the Aztecs and in Mesoamerica in general must be seen in the context of religious cosmology; sacrifice and death was necessary for the continued existence of the world. Likewise each part of life had one or more deities associated with it and these had to be paid their dues in order to achieve success. Gods were paid with sacrificial offerings of food, flowers, effigies, and quail. But the larger the effort required of the god, the greater the sacrifice. Blood fed the gods and kept the sun from falling. For some of the most important rites, a priest would offer his own blood, by cutting his ears, arms, tongue, thighs, chest, genitals, or offer a human life, or even a god's life. The people who were sacrificed came from many segments of society, and might be a war captive, slave, or a member of Aztec society.

Clergy are some of the main and important formal leaders within certain religions. The roles and functions of clergy vary in different religious traditions but these usually involve presiding over specific rituals and teaching their religion's doctrines and practices. Some of the terms used for individual clergy are clergyman, clergywoman and churchman. Less common terms are churchwoman, clergyperson and cleric.
Create Monks to increase a city's [ICON_PEACE] Faith output and to speed the creation of Great Prophet.

People of the ancient world were fascinated and awed by the forces of nature surrounding them. Earthquakes, storms and other phenomena were generally regarded as signs from heaven. Individuals and groups arose to formulate explanations for these events, and pass the knowledge along to the tribe. The priests and priestesses of mysticism, who were often called oracles, claimed union with the divine through meditation and trance-like contemplation. Primitive mysticism offered mankind the first, tenuous links with the powers that shaped their world, and represented the first move toward the organized polytheistic and monotheistic religions to come.
Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Shrine[ENDCOLOR], the first [ICON_PEACE] Faith producing building in the game.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Nature herself has imprinted on the minds of all the idea of God."[NEWLINE] - Cicero[NEWLINE][TAB]
Allows you to build various wonders and the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Garden[ENDCOLOR], which enhances your ability to create new [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People.
Allows your cities to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Granary[ENDCOLOR], which provides [ICON_FOOD] Food, helping your cities grow larger.

A priest is a person who leads worshippers in performing religious ceremonies and rituals. The position was of extraordinary importance in early cultures, since men believed that their day-to-day survival depended upon the favor of the gods. The earliest priests were probably elderly men and women too infirm to hunt and gather, but revered for their holiness and wisdom. As the lines between the spiritual and physical were much less rigid than today, priests might also be the tribal healers or leaders.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Many branches of Christianity, Hinduism and Buddhism still employ priests, and though their secular power is greatly diminished, in recent years priests have played important roles in getting societies to adopt social changes that benefit the people. In South America, priests are famous (or infamous) for their active participation in politics, while the late Pope John Paul II, the highest-ranking Roman Catholic priest, is given credit for hurrying the demise of the Soviet Union.
Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Temple[ENDCOLOR], which increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith output of a city.
Allows you to establish a State Religion.

In many world religions, there exist special communities and organizations of devout individuals who live apart from the majority of society, usually to keep more perfectly in line with their specific religious beliefs. These religious orders often take the physical form of monasteries, a building or complex where the pious can work and live.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While some religious orders were content to reside and pray in their native countries, some instead were founded for the sole purpose of expansion and spreading their beliefs to new peoples. The Jesuit missionaries in the Americas were one such religious order. These Jesuits traveled across the Atlantic and set up monasteries and missions on the American soil, where they taught the local people the tenets of their faith and the basics of western education.
Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Grand Inquisition[ENDCOLOR], which increases a civilization's [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety.
Allows you to hire Religious Orders as Mercenary Contracts.
Allows you to dis-establish your State Religion and become a secular civilization.

Replace.Text: Allows you to build a handful of specialized Wonders which improve your [ICON_PEACE] Faith output.

Row.Text: Earn [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety for the empire from each enemy unit killed. When Devout, the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital undergoes a perpetual [ICON_JFD_WLTKD] 'We Love the King Day.'
Is always eligible to found a Religion and can choose from Beliefs already in other Religions. Receive a free Great Prophet at the discovery of Theology.
No Religions Have Been Founded Yet
Palace provides +1 [ICON_CULTURE], [ICON_PEACE], [ICON_GOLD], [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE], [ICON_PRODUCTION], [ICON_RESEARCH]. +4 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism once Archaeology is discovered.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"My name is Ozymandias, king of kings: Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!" [NEWLINE]- Percy Bysshe Shelley[NEWLINE][TAB]

The Abu Simbel temples are two massive rock temples in Abu Simbel in Nubia, southern Egypt. They are situated on the western bank of Lake Nasser, about 230 km southwest of Aswan (about 300 km by road). The complex is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site known as the "Nubian Monuments," which run from Abu Simbel downriver to Philae (near Aswan).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The twin temples were originally carved out of the mountainside during the reign of Pharaoh Ramesses II in the 13th century BCE, as a lasting monument to himself and his queen Nefertari, to commemorate his alleged victory at the Battle of Kadesh. However, the complex was relocated in its entirety in 1968, on an artificial hill made from a domed structure, high above the Aswan High Dam reservoir.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The relocation of the temples was necessary to avoid their being submerged during the creation of Lake Nasser, the massive artificial water reservoir formed after the building of the Aswan High Dam on the Nile River.
[NEWLINE]"Three things cannot be long hidden: the sun, the moon, and the truth"[NEWLINE] - Buddha[NEWLINE]

The Buddhas of Bamiyan were two colossal Buddha statues, and hundreds of smaller ones, located in the province of Bamiyan in Afghanistan. All the Buddha on the site were carved out of cliff faces, and for several decades were a main tourist attraction of Afghanistan. The smaller of the two main statues was constructed in 507 CE, the other was constructed in 554 CE. The statues were originally coated in a mud and straw combination for finer details, which was then painted a variety of different colours. In man-made caves surrounding the Buddhas were what is believed to be the oldest examples of oil paintings ever found, dating to the fifth century CE. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In March 2001, the leader of the Taliban government declared that the statues were idols, and ordered their destruction. The two statues were dynamited in March and to this day remain as rubble around the area. Several proposals have since been made to restore the statues, these have been met by fierce opposition.
+2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture on all Faith-unlocked buildings. Provides a free Cathedral in the city in which it is built.
[NEWLINE]"The Gothic cathedral is a blossoming in stone subdued by the insatiable demand of harmony in man."[NEWLINE] - Ralph Wardo Emerson[NEWLINE]

Cologne Cathedral is a Roman Catholic cathedral, renowned for it’s stunning known for it’s impressive Gothic architecture. The cathedral is a World Heritage Site, known to have been the centerpiece of German Catholicism. Today the cathedral is the seat of the Archbishop of Cologne, and has risen to become one of Germany's most visited landmarks. Construction commenced in 1248, on the site of previous buildings such as a possible Roman temple and a granary. Construction on the structure ceased in 1473, and the cathedral remained unfinished for over four hundred years, not completed until the nineteenth century. Spurred on by romantic enthusiasm of the Middle Ages, and with the recovery of the original plans, the Prussian Court committed to completing the structure, despite being Protestant. In December of 1884, the Cologne Cathedral was finally completed. During the two World Wars of the early twentieth century the Cathedral suffered many major damages, and repair worked to be carried out for decades to come. Today, the Cologne Cathedral stands as a proud symbol of Germany’s rich cultural past, and a spiritual beacon to many Christians in Germany and around the world.
Gain [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety whenever you capture a city following your State Religion. Eliminates the [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety penalty from warring with Civilizations following your State Religion.
[NEWLINE]"No city in the world, not even Athens or Rome, ever played as great a role in the life of a nation for so long a time as Jerusalem."[NEWLINE] - David Ben-Gurion[NEWLINE]

Dome of the Rock is a colourful Islamic shrine located atop Temple Mount in the center of the city of Jerusalem. It was completed in 691 CE on the site of the Second Jewish Temple, and restored several times since. It is centered around the 'foundation rock', a rock upon which it is believed that the prophet Muhammed ascended to heaven. Interestingly, the Dome of the Rock was constructed not as a mosque, but rather as a shrine for Muslim pilgrims venturing to the Holy Land. Below the Dome of the Rock are a series of caverns which run throughout Jerusalem. These can be accessed via a crack in the Foundation Rock which leads to a cave known as the 'Well of Souls', a term made popular by the movie Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark. The exterior of the dome is made from porcelain and is octagonal in shape. Predominantly blue in the upper sections, islamic motifs cover the entire section. The dome is wooden with a 20 metre diameter and gold in colour.
Monks in this city yield +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith. Provides a free Monastery in the city in which it is built.

Replace.Text: Requires Piety. All Missionaries born in this city can spread religion an additional time. Provides a free Mosque in the city in which it is built.

Row.Text: Cities with a majority religion also get the Pantheon belief bonus of the second most popular religion.
[NEWLINE]"With every refinement they restored the Pantheon worn by age."[NEWLINE]- Septimius Severus and Caracalla.

Informally known as Santa Maria della Rotonda, the Pantheon is an ancient temple commissioned by Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa in 31 BC, after the historic Battle of Actium. The temple was part of a project launched by Augustus Caesar and his supporters where the region of Campus Martius begun more than twenty construction works there. The original building was destroyed with other buildings during a fire in 80, the emperor Domitian rebuilt the temple soon after but it too fell to ruin from a second fire in 110. The current temple was designed by Apollodorus of Damascus but who and how the temple was built is not known. In 609 the Byzantine emperor Phocas gave the building to Pope Boniface IV, who in turn converted the temple into a Christian church and consecrated it Sancta Maria ad Maytyres. The action spared it from abandonment and destruction. The Pantheon is today still used as a church and masses are attended regularly and weddings held there, although originally the Pantheon was used as a temple dedicated to the entire Pantheon of the Roman gods, hence the name.
A free Great Prophet appears.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Should this city be captured, the amount of [ICON_GOLD] Gold plundered by the enemy is tripled.
[NEWLINE]"All the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full."[NEWLINE] - King Solomon[NEWLINE][TAB]

Solomon's Temple, according to the Hebrew Bible, is an ancient, holy temple built by Solomon, King of the Israelites, destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon in his siege of Jersualem in 587 BCE. The Temple was dedicated to the god of Israel, Yahweh, and allegedly housed the legendary Ark of the Covenant. Because of the religious sensivity involved, it is difficult to determine much factual record of the Temple.
To maximize your bonus, make sure the Great Work Slots are filled with Artifacts.
Units purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith in this city earn [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points from kills. Provides a free Pagoda in the city in which it is built.
[NEWLINE]"The colour of the mountains is Buddha's body; the sound of running water is his great speech."[NEWLINE] - Dogen[NEWLINE]

Todai-ji is a Buddhist temple in the city of Nara in Japan. Its Great Buddha Hall displays the world’s largest bronze statue of the Buddha Vairocana and serves as the headquarters of the Kegon school of Buddhism in the country. Sika deer roam the grounds freely; they are regarded as messengers of the gods in Shinto.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The site of the temple was built during 728 by Emperor Shomu as an appeasement for his first son to consort Komyoshi, Prince Motoi, who died a year after his birth. The Tenpyo era followed and caused severe devastation and epidemics. These prompted Shomu to promote the construction of provincial temples across Japan. Known then as Kinshosen-ji, Shomu appointed Todai-ji the Provincial temple of Yamato Province and the head of all the temples. The complex maintained influence in the province and the rest of Japan until Japanese Buddhism moved from Nara to Mount Hiei and the capital of Japan moved to Kamakura during the mid ninth century.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The complex features many structures, all to appeal to the aesthetics of the garden designs. Over its history villas next to Todai-ji have become part of the complex, some of these are open to public viewing. Within the complex houses a number of architectural masterpieces; including the Nigatsu-do – the Hall of the Second Month - and the illustrious Daibutsuden – Great Buddha Hall.

When [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Devout, 20% of [ICON_PEACE] Faith contributes directly toward your next [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age. +15% [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_FOOD] Food during [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Ages.

The Temple of Heaven is a large temple complex located in Beijing, China. It was built by command of the Yongle Emperor, from 1406 to 1420. During the 16th century the temple was expanded and given its current name. In its history it has been used to practice Heaven Worship, Taoism and Confucisism. During the Second Opium War (1856 - 1860) The temple was occupied by the Anglo-French alliance, and during the 1900 Boxer Rebellion, it was occupied by the Eight-Nation Alliance. Both these occupations lead to the Temple falling into disrepair, and rumors of vandalism and theft by the occupiers.
[NEWLINE]"Death and life have their determined appointments; riches and honors depend upon heaven."[NEWLINE] - Confucius[NEWLINE]
Provides a free Shrine in the city in which it is built.
